About the diseases Treatment Projected damage estimation //leafblast Rice leaf blast, caused by the fungus Magnaporthe oryzae, is one of the most devastating diseases affecting rice crops. • Crop Rotation: Avoid planting rice in the same field consecutively. Rotate rice with other crops to break the disease cycle. 

• Beneficial Microorganisms: Some beneficial microorganisms, like certain strains of bacteria and fungi, can suppress the growth of the blast fungus. These can be applied to the soil or foliage as biological control agents. 

• Fungicides: Fungicides can be used to manage leaf blast. However, their use should be judicious to prevent the development of fungicide-resistant strains. Consult with local agricultural extension services for recommended fungicides and application methods. 

• Scouting: Regularly monitor your fields for signs of leaf blast. Early detection allows for timely intervention and can prevent the disease from spreading. 

• Residue Management: Properly dispose of crop residues after harvest. Infected plant material left in the field can harbor the fungus and contribute to the disease cycle. Blast infection can lead to great loss, there is a formula to calculate to get the estimated damage of the disease if it affects the plant. damage = area planted (ha) x 0.3 (if the damage is at 30%) or 0.5 (if the damage is at 50%) 

 DISCLAIMER: this computation is based on the estimation of the damage provided by the City Agricultural Office (CAGRO). other information on the computation method can be asked by the experts.


//sheathblight Rice sheath blight, caused by the fungus Rhizoctonia solani, is a significant disease that affects rice production worldwide. • Crop Rotation: Avoid planting rice in the same field continuously. Rotate rice with non-host crops to reduce the buildup of the pathogen in the soil. 

• Remove Infected Crop Residues: After harvest, remove and destroy infected crop residues to reduce the inoculum source for the next planting season. 

• Fungicide Timing: If the disease pressure is high and cultural practices alone are insufficient, consider applying fungicides. Timing is crucial; apply fungicides during the early stages of the disease when symptoms first appear. 

• Biocontrol Agents: Some beneficial microorganisms, such as Trichoderma spp., have been found to be effective in suppressing rice sheath blight. These can be applied as biocontrol agents. 

• Improving Drainage:Ensure proper field drainage to prevent waterlogged conditions, which can favor the development of sheath blight. One of the most significant effects of rice sheath blight is yield reduction. The disease affects the photosynthetic area of the rice plant, leading to poor grain filling and reduced kernel weight. There is a formula to calculate to get the estimated damage of the disease if it affects the plant. damage = area planted (ha) x 0.1 (if the damage is at 10%) or 0.5 (if the damage is at 50%) 

 DISCLAIMER: this computation is based on the estimation of the damage provided by the City Agricultural Office (CAGRO). other information on the computation method can be asked by the experts.


//brownspot Rice brown spot, caused by the fungus Bipolaris oryzae, is a common disease affecting rice plants. Its impacts on production can be significant and varied, depending on the severity of the infection, the rice variety, environmental conditions, and the stage of crop development. • Resistant Varieties: Planting rice varieties that are resistant or less susceptible to brown spot can be an effective strategy. Consult with local agricultural extension services or research institutions to identify suitable resistant varieties for your region. 

• Crop Rotation: Implement crop rotation practices to break the disease cycle. Avoid planting rice in the same field consecutively, as the pathogen can survive in crop debris. 

• Seed Treatment: Use disease-free, certified seeds and treat them with fungicides or hot water to reduce the risk of introducing the pathogen into the field through infected seeds. 

• Proper Irrigation: Avoid excessive or continuous flooding, as this can create favorable conditions for the disease. Use intermittent or alternate wetting and drying (AWD) irrigation practices to reduce disease incidence. 

• Fungicides: When the disease reaches damaging levels, chemical control may be necessary. Fungicides containing active ingredients like azoxystrobin, propiconazole, or tricyclazole are effective against rice brown spot. Follow the recommended application rates and timing provided on the product label. Brown spot affects the photosynthetic capacity of leaves, leading to reduced grain filling and ultimately reduced yield. There is a formula to calculate to get the estimated damage of the disease if it affects the plant. damage = area planted (ha) x 0.1 (if the damage is at 10%) or 0.5 (if the damage is at 50%) 

 DISCLAIMER: this computation is based on the estimation of the damage provided by the City Agricultural Office (CAGRO). other information on the computation method can be asked by the experts.


//leaffolder The rice leaffolder (Cnaphalocrocis medinalis) is a significant pest that affects rice production. Its impact can be quite detrimental, leading to reduced crop yields and economic losses. • Proper Field Hygiene: Remove and destroy crop residues after harvest to reduce overwintering sites for leaffolder larvae. 

• Natural Predators: Encourage natural predators like spiders, ladybugs, and parasitoid wasps, which feed on leaffolder larvae and eggs. 

• Insecticides: Chemical insecticides, such as pyrethroids and neonicotinoids, can be used to control leaffolders. However, their use should be judicious to prevent the development of pesticide resistance and minimize environmental impact. 

• Plant Resistant Rice Varieties: Plant rice varieties that are resistant or tolerant to leaffolder damage. Resistant varieties can significantly reduce the impact of the pest on crop yields. 

• Insecticide Application: If leaffolder populations are high and other control methods are insufficient, targeted insecticide applications can be considered. Consult with local agricultural extension services or entomologists to choose the right insecticide and application method. The main effect of rice leaf litter is the reduction of rice yield. The larvae of this pest feed on the green tissues of rice plants, including leaves, stems, and ears. This feeding damage reduces the ability of plants to photosynthesize, leading to stunted growth and reduced grain production. there is a formula to calculate to get the estimated damage of that disease if it affects the plant. damage = area planted (ha) x 0.1 (if the damage is at 10%) or 0.3 (if the damage is at 30%) 

 DISCLAIMER: this computation is based on the estimation of the damage provided by the City Agricultural Office (CAGRO). other information on the computation method can be asked by the experts.


//stemborer Rice stem borers are a group of insect pests that can have significant negative impacts on rice production. These pests belong to various species of moths and beetles, with the larvae (caterpillars) being the primary culprits. The most common rice stem borers include the yellow stem borer (Scirpophaga incertulas) and the striped stem borer (Chilo suppressalis). • Use Resistant Varieties: Plant rice varieties that are resistant or tolerant to stem borers. Resistant varieties can significantly reduce the impact of these pests on the crop 

• Natural Enemies: Encourage natural enemies of stem borers, such as parasitoid wasps and predators like birds and spiders, which feed on stem borer eggs and larvae. 

• Pesticides: Insecticides can be used when the pest population reaches an economic threshold and other control methods are not sufficient. Consult with local agricultural authorities or entomologists to determine the appropriate insecticides and application methods. 

• Integrated Pest Management (IPM): Implement an IPM approach, combining various control methods judiciously to minimize the use of chemical pesticides and reduce the impact on non-target organisms and the environment. 

• Proper Application: If pesticides are necessary, apply them at the recommended dosage and timing. Follow safety guidelines and local regulations regarding pesticide use. Rice stem borers damage rice plants by tunneling through the stems and feeding on the inner tissues. This feeding activity weakens the stems, reducing the plants ability to stand upright. As a result, rice plants can be straightened (fall over), leading to reduced grain filling and yield loss. there is a formula to calculate to get the estimated damage of that disease if it affects the plant. damage = area planted (ha) x 0.1 (if the damage is at 10%) or 0.3 (if the damage is at 30%) 

 DISCLAIMER: this computation is based on the estimation of the damage provided by the City Agricultural Office (CAGRO). other information on the computation method can be asked by the experts.


//tungro Rice tungro disease is a viral disease that affects rice plants. It is caused by the rice tungro spherical virus (RTSV) and the rice tungro bacilliform virus (RTBV), both of which are transmitted by the green leafhopper insect (Nephotettix virescens). This disease primarily affects rice crops and can lead to significant reductions in yield and quality. • Use Resistant Varieties: Plant rice varieties that are resistant to tungro disease. Resistant varieties can significantly reduce the impact of the disease on your crops. 

• Early Planting: Planting rice early in the season can help avoid the peak period of green leafhopper activity, reducing the chances of transmission of the virus. 

• Rouging: Remove and destroy infected plants as soon as symptoms are visible. This helps in reducing the source of the virus and prevents its spread to healthy plants. 

• Insecticide Application: Proper and timely application of insecticides can help control the green leafhopper population, which is responsible for transmitting the virus. Consult with agricultural experts or entomologists for advice on suitable insecticides and their application schedules. 

• Biological Control: Introduce natural predators and parasites of the green leafhopper, such as spiders and predatory insects, to help control their population naturally. Infected plants typically show stunted growth, reduced tillering, and smaller panicles. This leads to a significant decrease in the overall rice yield per hectare. there is a formula to calculate to get the estimated damage of that disease if it affects the plant. damage = area planted (ha) x 0.1 (if the damage is at 10%) or 0.3 (if the damage is at 30%) 

 DISCLAIMER: this computation is based on the estimation of the damage provided by the City Agricultural Office (CAGRO). other information on the computation method can be asked by the experts.


//Activity_book_card1 Seed Selection Using the recommendation type of "Certified seeds" Seeds of improved varieties of rice certified by the "National Seed Quality Control Services"(NCSQCS) can be identified or verified through a blue card (tag) that packed or bought in a bag. Can also use "Foundation or registered seeds" from reliable agencies like PhilRice and accredited growers Characteristics of seed certification •Clean and unadulterated or pure. 
•The grains are round or uniform in shape and size. 
•85 percent or more the "germination rate" or number of sprouts. Importance The use of certified seeds results in healthy plants that grow quickly and evenly. This will help to increase the yield of rice by about 5-10 percent. Recommendations Using a range type that has high yield potential, is available in the market (by traders/NFA), and is already undergoing plant testing ("technology demonstration" or "adaptability trial") in your area. 

Plant varieties of rice that are easy to grow old or those that can withstand being soaked in water in low-lying areas and are often flooded during the rainy season.

The varieties that should be planted in low-lying areas and with irrigation are: PSB Rc10 (Pagsanjan), NSIC Rc130 (Water 3), NSIC Rc152 (Water 10), NSIC Rc134 (Water 4) and NSIC Rc160 (Water 14). rainwater: NSIC Rc192 (Sahod Ulan), PSB Rc14 (Rio Grande), and PSB Rc68 (Sacobia). These rice varieties are also drought resistant. /n/n For upland or high areas that often experience drought: PSB Rc80 (Pasig), PSB Rc9 (Apo), and NSIC Rc23 (Katihan).



//Activity_book_card2 Field Preparation It is necessary that in the final leveling of the ground, there is no place that is too deep or shallow (The leveling of the land is the same.) During the leveling of the soil in the wetland, the depth of the water should be 2-5 centimeters. (Almost the width of the thumb of the hand.) There should be no visible soil that is compacted in the final leveling. Importance Good leveling of the wetland helps for proper and economical irrigation management, and also makes it easier to manage weeds and snails. Recommendations • Repair and clean the ditches and embankments.

• Plow the weeds and harvest or plow. Water the wetland twice or more (one week apart each time).

• Flatten the soil.


//Activity_book_card3 Planting A. Perform simultaneous planting after the soil has rested The wetland should be rested for about 30 days or more. It must also be planted within 14 days, before, and after, the common wetland belonging to the irrigation system is planted. Importance Through simultaneous planting, continuous breeding or multiplication of rice pests and diseases can be avoided. A month of resting in the wetland can interrupt the life cycle of fleas or insects and cause damage to disease habitats. Recommendations • Rest or do not cultivate the wetland for a month or more, from harvest, until the next crop.

• Plant rice at the same time as plant rice in the neighboring rice fields in your area. B. There should be a sufficient number of healthy cells. Transplanted Replant the dead plants (within 7 days of transplanting there should be 150 healthy plants, each square meter, while the rice field sown with 80 kilograms of seeds, there should be 300 or more, healthy plants, every one square meter of land. Importance Healthy plants grow quickly and can compete with weeds. Recommendations • Build a shelter near a water source, and protect it against vermin, especially against birds, snails and rats. The facility must also have a well-developed drainage system to facilitate the drainage of water.

• For sowing seeds. The field is ready to be sown with pre-planted seeds after plowing and harvesting. The sown seeds must be protected against birds, snails, rodents and weeds, following the correct method of managing the weeds. Sow the pre-sown seeds, in equal quantities, (per plot), in well-prepared and leveled soil.


//Activity_book_card4 Nutrient management Plants must have enough nutrients during the period of fertilization until "conception" and to bloom From objection to "conceived" and flowering, sprinkle with nitrogen fertilizer (1.5 bags of Urea per hectare in the summer, and one bag of urea per hectare in the rainy season), If the result of reading the "LCC" or "leaf Color Chart" less than four, for transplanted plants, and three for sown plants. Transplanted During the flowering period, there should be 300 ears or more, per square meter of wetland. Plant sowing During the flowering period, there should be about 350 ears or more, per square meter of wetland. Importance Getting enough nutrients from conception to "conception" and budding, helps for the good growth of rice, creating ears, and achieving the highest yield, according to the type of rice. The number of ears can be the basis of the number of harvests. Recommendations •Assess and provide the plant with this nitrogen requirement based on what is read in the LCC, as well as other nutrients required by the rice according to the MOET or the "Nutrient Ommission Plot ."

•Nitrogen(N). Use LCC every seven days from 14 days after transplanting or about 21 days from seeding, until it blooms or blooms. However, if spraying a complete fertilizer or 14-14-14-12S on the 14th day after transplanting, or 21 days after sowing, the LCC reading should be started on the 21st day. after transplanting, or on the 28th day after sowing.

•Phosphorus(P) and Potassium(K). The amount and type of fertilizer containing Pk and K, such as 14-14-14-12S, 16-20-0, 0-18-0, and 0-0-60 to be used, depends on the time of planting. , type of land, targeted yield, price, and its availability.

•Sulfur(S). The amount of sulfur contained in 14-14-14-12S (12%) recommended in Table 2 is sufficient to meet the deficiency of sulfur.

•Zinc(Zn). If zinc is lacking, use or add 25 kilograms of "zinc sulfate" per hectare, on the 14th day from transplanting. It will only be done once a year. Zinc, one of the types of "micronutrient" which is often lacking in wetlands. Symptoms of its deficiency will be noticed 2-4 weeks after transplanting.


//Activity_book_card5 Irrigation Management It is necessary to avoid excess or insufficient water that affects the growth of rice There should be no visible symptoms of overwatering while the rice is growing, such as few spikes and small leaves. Irrigation can be considered excessive if the minimum depth of the wetland is more than 5 centimeters for seven days or more.

There should also be no visible symptoms of insufficient irrigation, such as curling of the leaves (leaf rolling). , leaf tip drying, stunted growth, fewer ears, many seeds without flesh, from the time of growth, "breeding", until having fleshy grains . Importance Water carries nutrients from the soil to different parts of the plant. Proper irrigation results in healthy plants, with beautiful blossoms, normal growth, and large yields. Recommendations •The depth of water in the wetland should be about 3.5 centimeters, from the time of planting until about 1-2 weeks before harvesting. Drain wetlands 1-2 weeks before harvest.

•For "galas" soils, Drain wetlands about a week before harvest.

•However on soils that are "sticky" or muddy, drain the wetland about two weeks before harvest.


//Activity_book_card6 Managing Processes The harvest should not be reduced because of the weather The harvest should not decrease due to diseases, diseases, weeds, mice and birds. The damage that can be done by any of these factors is great. Importance The management of rice fields is an important part of rice cultivation. The information about the relationship or interaction of rice and the creatures (with life) that can affect its growth (biotic factors), environment (agro-ecosystem), and methods or systems of plant cultivation, will surely help in determining the ability of weeds to cause damage to rice fields. Recommendations •Choose to plant varieties of rice that have high resistance against diseases that are common in your area.

•Protect (take care of) those who help. or beneficial organisms.

•Conduct regular inspection of rice fields and control rice pests such as insects, diseases, weeds, rodents, snails, and birds. It is best if the entire barangay or community cooperates in conducting this.


//Activity_book_card7 Seed Selection See and harvest the rice at the right time Rice is ripe when 20 percent of the grains at the end of the ear are rock hard, or when most of the grains in the ear are golden.

 
You can tell if the rice grains are hard by squeezing them with your thumb. Importance Proper harvesting and threshing results in quality rice grains, and they can be sold at a high price in the market. Recommendations •The rice is ready when 80% of the grains are golden or when only 20-25 percent of the moisture content or "moisture content" of this, in the rainy season and 18-21% in the summer.

•It is suggested to use a "grain moisture meter"

•The rice is soaked for a period not exceeding one days from harvesting during the rainy season, and not more than two days, during the hot season.

•Make sure that the thresher is clean and that the "settings" this Rice drying Dry wet rice within 24 hours after harvesting to prevent it from turning black. Here are the methods you can choose to dry rice: 

•Blow it in the sun, or not,

•Use a mechanical facility such as a Flat Bed Dryer (FBD) especially during the dry season. rain. The FBD has the capacity to dry 120 sacks of rice in 10 to 12 hours. If using FBD, be sure to follow the correct drying time so that it does not result in low quality rice grains.
